coredata.dc:title: Structural changes in simple liquids during extreme shearing
coredata.dc:creator: Heyes, D.M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The structural changes that take place in simple liquids during extreme shear thinning and the subsequent start of shear thickening are elucidated by non-equilibrium molecular dynamics. Long-range order develops, which is characterised by linear lines of molecules spontaneously forming along the shear flow lines. These “strings” of molecules pack into a triangular lattice. The density of strings increases with shear rate, as does the difference in density in various directions with respect to the flow field. Local structural asymmetry and a lengthening of relaxation times are observed at the highest shear rates considered, leading eventually to structural and dynamical disorder and inchoate shear thickening.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 STRUCTURAL CHANGES IN SIMPLE LIQUIDS DURING EXTREME SHEARING D.M. HEYES Department of Chemistry, Royal Hollo-way and Bedford New College (University of London), Egham, Surrey TW200EX, UK Received 10 June 1985; in final form 7 April 1986 The structural changes that take place in simple liquids during extreme shear thinning and the subsequent start of shear thickening are elucidated by non-equilibrium molecular dynamics. Long-range order develops, which is characterised by linear lines of molecules spontaneously forming along the shear flow lines. These "strings" of molecules pack into a triangular lattice. The density of strings increases with shear rate, as does the difference in density in various directions with respect to the flow field. Local structural asymmetry and a lengthening of relaxation times are observed at the highest shear rates considered, leading eventually to structural and dynamical disorder and inchoate shear thickening. 1. Introduction There have been a number of investigations of the theological behaviour of classical simple liquids using the computer simulation technique of non-equilibrium molecular dynamics (NEMD) which have clarified a number of features of their non-Newtonian responses [ 1,2]. These studies have shown that model simple liquids respond to shearing in much the same way as more experimentally accessible complicated liquids if the shear rates for the simple liquids are of the same order as the relaxational frequencies of the component molecules (in the THz range). The common aspects are as follows [1 4]. Under steady-state conditions and at shear rates below 5 X 1010 s~1 for argon (or a shear rate of 0.1 in Lennard- Jones pair potential reduced units) the shear viscosity is essentially independent of shear rate. This is called the first-Newtonian viscosity region. Then over approx- imately two decades increase in shear rate there is an ever more precipitous drop in shear viscosity which leads eventually, within a relatively narrow shear rate in- crease, to a dramatic decrease in the value of the vis- cosity. This extreme "shear-thinning" develops into another shear rate regime in which the viscosity hardly diminishes the so-called second-Newtonian region. Then at even higher shear rates the properties of the material alter so that the shear viscosity often increases markedly ("shear-thickening"). 0 009-2614/86/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) NEMD is a powerful modelling technique in that it provides all the positions and velocities of the modelled liquid molecules and therefore many other aspects of the sheared material can be analysed. It has been re- vealed that these different regimes of viscosity are associated with phase changes in the liquids, which should be independent of the method used for shear- ing (whether homogeneous or boundary driven) [ 1,5,6]. The region of rapid decrease in viscosity, for example, is associated with a change from an essentially amor- phous liquid structure to a "string" phase, in which lines of molecules form along the shear streamlines and pack into a triangular lattice, when viewed in a plane orthogonal to their length. These strings are very slow to drift en masse and appear stationary when viewed in cross section over many Maxwell relaxation times [ 1 ]. This regime of extreme shear thinning, which in- volves a change from short-range to long-range order is now well characterised. In contrast, the structural and dynamical changes that take place in this ordered phase on going through the second-Newtonian region and incipient shear thickening are still poorly under- stood. Consequently, a series of NEMD simulations has been performed on a model simple liquid to inves- tigate the structural and dynamical changes that take place at these high shear rates, of a magnitude only recently explored [4]. 515 Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 2. The model and discussion Computations were performed on cubic MD cells containing 256 Lennard-Jones (12 6) molecules at the reduced density ofp*= 0.8442 and T* = 0.722, which is close to the triple point for this pair poten- tial [7]. The direct imposition of a linear velocity pro- file using the SLLOD algorithm [8] was accompanied by the Gaussian isokinetic scheme of velocity control to achieve a fixed kinetic energy ("temperature") [9]. The sides of the MD cell are along the x,y and z direc- tions and shearing is in the xz plane, where the stream- ing flow is along the x direction. The Verlet algorithm was modified to perform these dynamical perturbations and was used with a fixed time step for integrating the equations of motion [10]. Computational stability was maintained by reducing the time step at higher strain rates. Four calculations were performed; one at a point in the moderately shear thinning part of the rheogram (7 = 0.8), and two on either side (shear thinning and thickening) of the second-Newtonian region: at 7 = 5.0 and 50.0, respectively. Another point at 7 = 25 was also obtained. Details about the calculations are given in table 1. The shear viscosity, r), reaches a mini- mum at shear rates between T? = 5 and 7=50. Calcu- lations at T? = 0.8, 5, 10, 25 and 50 produce T? values of 2.22,0.34, 0.20, 0.03 and 0.13. Therefore at 7 = 50 the shear thickening is just starting to become evi- dent after the second-Newtonian regime. The shear thinning part of this rheogram is inde- pendent of the past history of shear rates and number of particles in the cell. For example, at a shear rate of 0.8 independent simulations performed with./V= 256 and 2048 gave viscosities of 2.20 and 2.22, respective- ly. Similarly at a shear rate of 5.0 viscosities of 0.34 and 0.31 were obtained [11]. These are statistically the same as the present results because shear thinning occurs at shear rates at which a steady state can be achieved. In contrast, shear thickening is a fundamental- ly different phenomenon that is caused by departures from steady state into a metastable state which has a long lifetime compared with any practical observation time. This is the duration of the simulation in this study. As the shear rate is increased at an arbitrary rate, y, there comes a value of 7 at which the molecules cannot adapt sufficiently rapidly to the shear distor- tions and the molecules overlap appreciably to form highly stressed and largely structurally arrested states. The stress grows and the diagonal elements of the pressure tensor can take on negative values, assisted in this by the effective finite size of the system imposed by the periodic boundary conditions. This also hinders the structural relaxation on a corresponding distance scale, which in a real experiment is the size of the con- tainer. In both simulation and experiment we are witnes- sing a divergence in correlation lengths and times caused by the magnitude of the shear rate. In a real experiment the sample is seen to fracture because of the extra constrictions imposed by the finite size of the container. Consequently, the shear rate at which shear thicknening is first observed depends on the rate of change of shear rate up to that point. The smaller 7 is, the more time the system has to accommodate the shear strains by structural reorganisation over long distance scales compared with the molecular diameter and shear thickening then occurs at higher shear rates. This has been observed in this study. Here shear rate increments of 25 reduced units lead to incipient shear thickening at 7 = 50, whereas steps of 10 reduced units postpone this transition until a shear ratio of 100, for both N = 256 and N = 2048. The apparent viscosity at this shear rate is 0.9 reduced units [11]. In fact, if one adopted an inifintely small shear rate increment and infinitely sized system then shear thickening would never arise. The second-Newtonian regime would extend to infinite shear rates. The exact shear rate at which 17 increases and the precise proper- ties of these states are therefore not of major concern because of associated hysteresis. The main interest in this study is to characterise the second-Newtonian plateau in between exteme shear thinning and shear thickening, and to ascertain the effects of periodic sys- tems on this region of the rheogram. During the rapidly shear thinning part of viscosity versus shear rate curve the liquid structure changes and becomes more ordered. Long range structural correla- tions appear which have many similarities with the liquid to crystal phase transition. Therefore the pres- sure drops at constant volume. Unlike the latter tran- sition, the anisotropy imposed on the system by the shear flow produces diagonal pressure tensor compo- nents, P^^, which are unequal and respond differently to the ordering. The shear creates lines of molecules along the streaming, x, direction which pack into a 516 Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 trigonal lattice, when viewed in cross section. This results in Py^ becoming negative due to an anisotropic reorganisation of density, of a form discussed below. At this thermodynamic state point the transition from amorphous liquid to the "string phase" takes place sharply at 7 = 2.3 0.1 [10]. The string phase is evident for the 7 = 5.0 and y = 50.0 states in fig. 1. For each state the figure shows a planar projection of all of the molecular coordinates onto theyz plane. The triangular lattice is well formed with little evidence of a thermal spread of positions about the average over the 7 = 2.5 to 50.0 range. However the number of strings is markedly different for these two states. Fig. 1 reveals that tnere are 46 strings at 7 = 5.0 and 66 at 7 (a) y :b) = 50.0. As there are 256 molecules in the MD cell that means there are, on average, 6 and 4 molecules per MD cell, respectively, in each string along the x direc- tion. The average number of molecules in the z, y and x directions is roughly 7 X 7 X 6 and 8 X 8 X 4, re- spectively. Molecules are forced out of strings with increasing shear rate to form a larger number of strings, when viewed in cross section. This is also manifest in the negative values for P^ at 7 = 5 and 25. Finite size effects created by the periodic boundary conditions (here for-/V= 256) do therefore have an effect on some properties even with the second-Newtonian re- gime. This becomes more important with increasing 7 and contributes to the production of shear thickening here at somewhat lower shear rates than would be the case for an infmitely sized system. There are a number of other structural and related dynamical changes which eventually cause an up-turn in the viscosity. A convenient probe for these is pro- vided by the pair radial distribution function, g(r), and its angular components [6], ^p(r)=15^p(/ )/47r'or2dr. where f^(r) is the average of (faijrsiilri^ m tne "dial element r -* r + dr about a molecule; r^ is the a- Cartesian component ofr,,, the vector between mol- ecules i and/. Each molecule is taken as the origin in turn to improve the statistical reliability of this func- tion. First we consider the pair radial distribution func- tions. The^(r) for the 7 = 5.0 and 50.0 states are corn- Fig. 1. Instantaneous configurations for N = 256 states. The coordinates of all the molecules are projected onto the_yz plane (a) 7 = 5.0 and (b) 7 = 50.0. The interactions were trun- cated at half - the MD cell's sidelength. The shearing is in the xz plane. The x direction is the streaming direction. Fig. 2. Pair radial distribution function for the y = 5.0 state. The insert is tor 7 = 50.0. 517 Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 pared in fig. 2. The trend is for the peaks to move to smaller separations as shear rate increases. The first "coordination" shell has a radius about 0.2 a smaller, while the second shell is about 0.5 o smaller in radius. The g(r) is noisier at 7 = 50 than 7 = 5 because, with increasing shear rate, the glancing collisions between particles in neighbouring strings become more ener- getic. Therefore these collisions can knock rows tem- porarily out of alignment, albeit still within the same "string" phase framework. Consequently the peaks in g(r) become less smooth. The angular components of the pair radial distribu- tion function, g^a(r) are informative in illuminating other differences in structures between these two states. Fig. 3 compares the g^(r) for the 7 = 5.0 and 50.0 states. The only major asymmetry at the lower shear rate takes place within the second coordination shell. The main peak for j^O") is at r = 2.2 a whereas the other two components show this at r = 1.8. How- ever, at 7 = 50.0 the first coordination shell shows evidence ot a major distortion. The inward movement referred to above, from theg(r), is confined to they and z directions (orthogonal to the streaming direc- tion). The positions of the peaks in gy^r) are hardly distinguishable from those at 7 = 5.0, although they are somewhat more spread out. This suggests (as for the above planar coordinate projections) that the density of the sample becomes significantly more ani- (0) ;b) 1.2 0.4 -0.4 -1.2 el, - ^>A--V- ":ii ''.' '.. .' 3 Pig. 3. The angular pair distribution functions: gJcx(r), gyy, - w&Szs, (a) -r = 5.0 and (b) 7 = 50.0. 518 Pig. 4. The angular pair distribution functions: gw, ; Sxz' --- and Syz,.... (a) -y = 5.0 and (b) 7 = 50.0. Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 sotropic with increasing shear rate. A common assump- tion in classical treatises on rheology is the incompres- sibility of the liquid under shear [12]. In contrast, these calculations demonstrate that these simple liquids are highly compressible when they exhibit non-Newton- ian rheology. The asymmetric expansion components, g^g(r), are shown for these states in fig. 4. One expects g^(r) to deviate from zero on average. To a very good ap- proximation this is reproduced by -Ae^r(3go/3r), where gy is the pair radial distribution function in the absence of shear and Ae^ is the so-called recoverable shear strain [6]. Best fit values for Ae^ at shear rates of 0.8,5.0 and 50.0 are 0.07,0.06 and 0.015, respec- tively. (In the latter case the fit is less satisfactory be- cause the actual ^(r) decays more rapidly to zero, by r = 1.2, than the above expansion predicts.) There- fore, increasing the shear rate in this part of the rheo- gram leads to a decrease in recoverable shear strain. The concept of a limiting shear stress, popular in phenomenological theories of shear thinning, has some merit [13]. Indeed, the shear stress even decreases during extreme shear thinning, as the decrease in re- coverable shear strain would imply if one equated Table 1 State parameters for LJ simulations at p * = 0.8442 and T* = 0.722. All quantities are in LJ reduced units. The standard deviation (X2) - (X)2 is evaluated from data at each time step. Note that the uncertainty limits in the means <.X> given by the standard error will be smaller Property X T =0.8 7=5 7 25 7 =50 <.X) (X2) - (X)2 (.X) (X2) - (X)2 (X) (X2) - (X)2 (X} (X2) - (X)2 Af 0.005 0.003 0.0005 0.001 0.007 T 0.722 0.003 0.723 0.015 0.724 0.010 0.722 0.007 <D -5.923 0.057 -5.999 0.081 -6.013 0.106 4.912 1.026 E -4.840 0.055 -4.91 0.080 -4.93 0.10 5.995 1.026 pk' XX 0.63 0.045 0.57 0.052 0.81 0.10 0.34 0.07 ^y 0.59 0.044 0.53 0.046 0.51 0.06 0.65 0.11 P^z 0.61 0.044 0.74 0.051 0.51 0.10 0.84 0.11 Pxx 0.98 0.43 -0.86 0.42 -0.10 0.50 9.08 2.10 Pyy 0.75 0.40 1.50 0.53 2.85 0.72 56.81 4.76 PZZ 1.09 0.43 1.77 0.63 0.22 0.76 72.84 8.03 *12 6.12 0.11 6.11 0.14 6.04 0.16 22.11 1.32 t-6 -12.04 0.06 -12.11 0.08 -12.05 0.09 -17.20 0.31 xy 25.14 1.73 15.08 1.55 8.21 1.39 66.30 5.32 xz 25.05 2.02 5.79 1.52 -1.45 1.42 20.64 9.29 ys 25.50 1.72 32.95 2.38 32.81 2.76 181.4 17.7 ^ 0.001 0.04 0.045 0.04 0.02 0.08 0.0001 0.09 pk 'xz -0.064 0.038 -0.209 0.044 -0.25 0.08 -0.38 0.06 pkfyZ 0.001 0.04 -0.151 0.06 -0.18 0.096 -0.003 0.10 pxy 0.011 0.272 -0.49 0.34 -0.76 0.37 -0.15 1.98 PXZ -1.78 0.29 -1.68 0.31 -0.71 0.32 -6.29 2.16 Pyz -0.004 0.268 -1.23 0.47 -1.44 0.52 -0.40 3.15 ri 2.22 0.41 0.34 0.07 0.028 0.015 0.13 0.04 a 0.78 0.62 4.59 1.18 9.64 5.04 172.5 33.6 NT 27000 30000 27000 15000 519 Volume 127, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 27 June 1986 the shear stress to the product of the shear rigidity modulus and the recoverable shear strain. (The former is less sensitive to conditions in this regime and, in fact, also decreases with increasing shear rate [10].) This trend also means that the shear viscosity decreases more rapidly than the shear rate increases during ex- treme shear thinning. Another notable trend is the appearance of statis- tically significant gyy(r) and gy^(r), of comparable magnitude to^(r) for 7 = 5 and 25. These produce finite non-zero P^y and P which are statistically sig- nificant and reproducible at 7 = 5. From symmetry arguments one would expect the properties ofxy and yz symmetry to average to zero over long times. How- ever there is no evidence of this at these shear rates. The averages and mean square deviation of the calcu- lated quantities in table 1 are statistically well defined (as evident in subaverage analyses) up to and including 7 = 50. There is a paradox in that although these are well defined and reproducible steady states for the viscosity and diagonal pressure tensor components (except for 7 = 50), other properties from them are metastable. This symmetry breaking is expected during shear thickening. However, it is also evident here even within the second-Newtonian regime because a finite sized MD cell within a periodic infinite system hinders long range structural relaxation over a distance scale com- parable to that of the dimensions of the MD cell. Certain asymmetric structures can persist in the cell for periods of time which are much longer than a fea- sible simulation can hope to exceed. Hence novel struc- tural relaxation mechanisms in the highly sheared liq- uid characterised by very long relaxation times are evident for a finite system prior to shear thickening. In fact, the appearance of symmetry breaking flow patterns during extreme flow ("shear") rates is a well- documented phenomenon in flow realisation experi- ments of liquids converging from a wide to a narrow channel [14]. It is reassuring that equivalent phenom- ena occur in these microscopic models. All g^r) be- come small by almost an order of magnitude on in- creasing 7 from 5.0 to 50.0. Also they become generally more short-ranged, indicating that there are more local- ised structural distortions on the shear thickening side of the second-Newtonian plateau. It is the lenghtening of shear stress and structural relaxation times with 7 (observed here) which ultimately gives rise to shear thickening but does also have an influence on certain 520 system properties even within the second-Newtonian regime for periodic systems. Calculations of velocity, force and pressure tensor component time autocorrelation functions, the com- ponent shear rigidity moduli and the component self- diffusion coefficients have revealed the dynamical as- pects of these states [10]. The string phase has charac- teristics of a solid in directions orthogonal to the stream- ing direction but it is liquid-like along the flow lines. The establishment of a "two time-scale" material is a consequence of the string phase. Oscillations appear in the orthogonal direction autocorrelation functions of a frequency of order 7. Woodcock (Bradford University), Dr. J.R. Melrose, Dr. J.V.L. Singer and Professor K. Singer of this department. The RHBNC VAX 11/780 was used to perform these computations. [12] W.R. Schowalter, Mechanics of non-Newtonian fluids (Pergamon Press, Oxford, 1978). [13] S. Bair and W.O. Winer, ASME J. Lub. Techn. 101 (1979)258. [14] M.J. Crochet, A.R. Davies and K. How- ever there is no evidence of this at these shear rates. The averages and mean square deviation of the calcu- lated quantities in table 1 are statistically well defined (as evident in subaverage analyses) up to and including 7 = 50. There is a paradox in that although these are well defined and reproducible steady states for the viscosity and diagonal pressure tensor components (except for 7 = 50), other properties from them are metastable. This symmetry breaking is expected during shear thickening. However, it is also evident here even within the second-Newtonian regime because a finite sized MD cell within a periodic infinite system hinders long range structural relaxation over a distance scale com- parable to that of the dimensions of the MD cell. Hence novel struc- tural relaxation mechanisms in the highly sheared liq- uid characterised by very long relaxation times are evident for a finite system prior to shear thickening. head.ce:title: Structural changes in simple liquids during extreme shearing

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The structural changes that take place in simple liquids during extreme shear thinning and the subsequent start of shear thickening are elucidated by non-equilibrium molecular dynamics. Long-range order develops, which is characterised by linear lines of molecules spontaneously forming along the shear flow lines. These “strings” of molecules pack into a triangular lattice. The density of strings increases with shear rate, as does the difference in density in various directions with respect to the flow field. Local structural asymmetry and a lengthening of relaxation times are observed at the highest shear rates considered, leading eventually to structural and dynamical disorder and inchoate shear thickening.
